case_name: Amritdhara Pharmacy v. Satya Deo Gupta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 22 of 1960 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CiviL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 22 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 19, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in F. A. No. 62 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 19, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in F. A. No. 62

facts.text: Special leave granted by this Court on December 8, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave granted by this Court on December 8, 1958.

facts.text: Satya Deo Gupta, respondent, made an application under s. 14 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940 for registration of the trade name Lakshmandhara on July 19, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On July 19, 1950, Satya Deo Gupta, respondent before us, made an application under a. 14 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940  Act V

facts.text: Application for registration in Class 5 of the Fourth Schedule to the Trade Marks Rules, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: for registration of the trade name of a biochemical medicinal preparation, companymonly known as Laksbmandhara, in Class 5

facts.text: Applicant is sole proprietor of Rup Bilas Company situate at Dhankutti in Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The application was made by the respondent as the sole proprietor of Rup Bilas Company situate, at Dhankutti in Kanpur.

facts.text: Medicinal preparation Lakshmandhara in use since 1923, sold throughout India and foreign markets, annual turnover Rs. 40,000/- approx.

anchor.surface_text: The averments made in the application were that the said medicinal preparation had been in use by the name of Lakshmandhara since 1923

facts.text: Amritdhara Pharmacy filed opposition to the application.

anchor.surface_text: Notice of the application was given by the Registrar of Trade Marks, Bombay, and the Amrit dhara Pharmacy... filed an application in opposition.

facts.text: Amritdhara trade name registered for medicinal preparation introduced in 1901.

anchor.surface_text: In this application the appellant stated that the word Amritdhara was already registered as a trade name for the medicinal preparation

facts.text: Amritdhara medicine commenced business in 1901 by Pandit Thakur Datta Sharma at Lahore for ayurvedic medicine alleviating headaches, diarrhoea, constipation etc.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar found that in 1901 Pandit Thakur Datta Sharma companymenced to do business at Lahore in a particular ayurvedic medicine

facts.text: Name changed from Amrit Ki Dhara to Amritdhara in 1903.

anchor.surface_text: This medicine was first sold under the mark Amrit Ki Dhara, but in 1903 the name was changed to Amritdhara,

facts.text: Limited liability company formed in 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Pandit Thakur Datta Sharma formed a limited liability companypany in 1942

facts.text: After partition in 1947, business established in Dehradun.

anchor.surface_text: The business was done in Lahore but when partition came in 1947, the appellant established its business in Dehradun.

facts.text: Registrar of Trade Marks order dated September 10, 1953, allowing registration of Lakshmandhara limited to Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of Trade Marks dealt with the application and the opposition thereto by his order dated September 10, 1953.

facts.text: Registrar found names likely to deceive or cause confusion under s.8 and s.10(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar expressed the view that if the matter had rested on s. 8 and s. 10 1  of the Act, he world have numberhesitation

facts.text: Honest concurrent user of Lakshmandhara since 1923 found by Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: On the point of honest companycurrent user the Registrar found in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: Acquiescence found by Registrar in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: As to acquiescence he, however, found in favour of the respondent

facts.text: Respondent admitted goods sold mainly in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Registrar it was admitted on behalf of the respondent that his goods were sold mainly in, Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment dated March 19, 1958, allowed respondent's appeal for registration whole India, dismissed appellant's.

anchor.surface_text: They accordingly allowed the appeal of the respondent and dismissed that of the appellant by their judgment dated March 19, 1958.

facts.text: Supreme Court found overall structural and phonetic similarity likely to deceive or cause confusion.

anchor.surface_text: To such a man the overall structural and phonetic similarity of the ,two names Amritdhara and Lakshmandbara is, in our, opinion likely.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with Registrar on acquiescence, restored order limiting to Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: the Registrar was right in imposing the limitation which he imposed. For these reasons, we would allow the appeal, set aside the Judgment

facts.text: Lakshmandhara user commenced in small way in 1923, insignificant up to 1942.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before me it is number disputed that the applicant companymenced his user in a small way in 1923 and it may even be said

facts.text: Annual turnover of Lakshmandhara about Rs. 43,000/- in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: from small beginning he began to sell these medicines to the extent of about Rs. 43,000/-in 1949.

facts.text: Amritdhara sales about Rs. 4 lacs a year.

anchor.surface_text: The sale of the medicine went up to about Re. 4 lacs a year.

facts.text: Two appeals to Allahabad High Court under s.76 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: From the decision of the Registrar two appeals were referred to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad under s. 76 of the Act

issues.text: whether the name Lakshmandhara was likely to deceive the public or cause confusion to trade within the meaning of s. 8 and s. 10 1 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The first point is whether the name Lakshmandhara was likely to deceive the public or cause confusion to trade within the meaning of s. 8 and s. 10 1 of the Act.

issues.text: whether there was Such, acquiescence on behalf of the appellant in the use of the name Lakshmandhara in the. State of Uttar Pradesh as to bring it within the, expression special circumstances mentioned in sub-s. 10 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The second point is whether there was Such, acquiescence on behalf of the appellant in the use of the name Lakshmandhara in the. State of Uttar Pradesh as to bring it within the, expression special circumstances mentioned

issues.text: whether the Registrar of Trade Marks was justified in taking into consideration the decisions in those cases

anchor.surface_text: A question has been raised before us whether the Registrar of Trade Marks was justified in taking into consideration the decisions in those cases. To that question we shall advert later.

arguments.claim: Lakshmandhara so nearly resembles registered Amritdhara as to be likely to deceive or cause confusion

anchor.surface_text: In this application the appellant stated that the word Amritdhara was already registered as a trade name for the medicinal preparation of the appellant, and that medicinal preparation was introduced in the market so far back as in the year 1901 on account of its great popularity many people advertised similar medicines with slight variations of name to pass off their goods as Amritdhara.

arguments.court_reasoning: Overall structural and phonetic similarity likely to deceive average purchaser with imperfect recollection

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent a counter-affidavit was made in which it was stated that Amritdhara and Lakshmandhara were two distinctly different names and no one could pass off one for the other.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unwary purchaser considers overall similarity, not etymology

arguments.claim: No monopoly on common words like Amrit and dhara; confined to whole phrase

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the Amritdhara pharmacy that both the words Amrit and dhara have become so associated- with their goods that the use of each part separately or in any combination is likely to mislead is an, untenable claim. The whole phrase Amritdhara had been registered and the Monopoly has to be confined only to the use of the whole word.

They said that from the fact that both the medicines were being advertised in-the same journals or periodicals it did not, following that the attention of the appellant was, drawn to the use of the word Lakshmandhara by the respondent.

arguments.claim: Names likely to deceive under s.8 s.10(1) per multi-factor test

anchor.surface_text: The first point is whether the name Lakshmandhara was likely to deceive the public or cause confusion to trade within the meaning of s. 8 and s. 10 1 of the Act... To such a man the overall structural and phonetic similarity of the ,two names Amritdhara and Lakshmandbara is, in our, opinion likely.

arguments.claim: Consider marks as wholes, not parts; overall impression for average imperfect recollection purchaser

anchor.surface_text: The Act does not lay down any criteria... You must take the two words. You must judge them, both by their look and by their sound... A trade mark is the whole thing the whole word has to be considered a the case of the application to register Erectiks...

arguments.claim: Prior decisions admissible under s.13 Evidence Act but unnecessary here

anchor.surface_text: As to the decisions in annexure A, it has been argued before us that they were not at all admissible by reason of ss. 40 to 43 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. On behalf of the appellant it has been contended that they were admissible under s. 13 of the Evidence.

arguments.court_reasoning: Do not throw light on similarity between these marks

arguments.claim: Acquiescence established: stood by while respondent built reputation to Rs.43,000 turnover

anchor.surface_text: Here again we are in agreement with the Registrar of Trade Marks... The finding of the Registrar is that the appellant and its agent were well aware of the advertisements of the respondent, and the appellant stood by and allowed the respondent to develop his business till it grew from a small beginning in 1923 to an annual turnover of Rs. 43,000/- in 1946.

arguments.claim: Appellant not claiming monopoly in dhara but exclusive right under s.21 to oppose confusing marks

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we think that the High Court was. right in thinking that the appellant was claiming a. monopoly in the common Hindi word dhara. We do not think that is quite the position here. What the appellant is claiming is its right under s. 21 of the Act, the exclusive right to the use of its trade mark,

holdings.text: The overall similarity between the two names Amritdhara and Lakshmandhara in respect of the same description of goods was likely to cause deception or confusion within the meaning of s. 10(1) of the Act; the Registrar was right and the High Court erred.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of all the circumstances, we have companye to the companyclusion that the overall similarity between the two names in respect of the same description of goods was likely to cause deception or companyfusion within the meaning of s. 10 1  of the Act and Registrar was right in the view he expressed. The High Court was in error taking a companytrary view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor test from precedents (Pianotist): judge by look/sound/goods/customers/surrounding circumstances; overall impression to average intelligence imperfect recollection purchaser, not etymology or dissection.

holdings.text: Acquiescence established by appellant standing by while respondent built business from 1923 to Rs.43,000 turnover in 1949 mainly in Uttar Pradesh, constituting special circumstances under s.10(2); Registrar right to limit registration to Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Here again we are in agreement with the Registrar of Trade Marks, who in a paragraph of his order quoted earlier in this judg- ment has summarised the facts and circumstances on which the plea of acquiescence was based... the Registrar was right in imposing the limitation which he imposed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed with Registrar's findings on awareness via ads/agents, no protest allowing reputation build-up; per Halsbury, acquiescence debars complaint; admission of main sales in UP justifies limit.

holdings.text: Unnecessary to decide whether prior decisions in annexure A admissible under s.13 Evidence Act as they do not assist on similarity between Amritdhara and Lakshmandhara.

anchor.surface_text: As to the decisions in annexure A, it has been argued before us that they were number at all admissible by reason of ss. 40 to 43 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. On behalf of the appellant it has been companytended that they were admissible under s. 13 of the Evidence. Act as showing the particular instances... We companysider it unnecessary to decide this question for the purposes of this case because those decisions even if they are admissible under s. 13 do number throw any light on the question whether Amritdhara and Lakshmandhara so nearly resemble each other as to cause deception or companyfusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue raised but decision avoided as prior cases irrelevant to specific marks' similarity; determined independently as first impression.

holdings.text: Appellant not claiming monopoly in common word 'dhara' but exclusive right under s.21 to oppose registration of confusingly similar mark.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we think that the High Court was. right in thinking that the appellant was claiming a. monopoly in the companymon Hindi word dhara. We do number think that is quite the position here. What the appellant is claiming is its right under s. 21 of the Act, the exclusive right to the use of its trade mark, and to oppose the registration of a trade mark which go nearly resembles its trade mark that it is likely to deceive or cause companyfusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corrected High Court's mischaracterization; s.21 confers right to oppose deceptively similar marks regardless of common elements.

precedents.citation: Pianotist Co. s Application 1906 23 R. P. C. 774,777

anchor.surface_text: Pianotist Co. s Application (1 ), which was also a case of the companyparison of two words- You must take the two words. You must Judge them, both by their look and by their sound. You must companysider the goods to which they are to be applied. You must companysider the nature and kind of customer who would be likely to buy those goods. In fact you must companysider all the surrounding circumstances and you must further companysider what is likely to happen if each of those trade marks is used in a numbermal way as a trade mark for the goods of the respective owners of the marks 1 1906 23 R. P. C. 774,777.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tests for determining deceptive resemblance of trade marks: judge words by look and sound, consider goods, nature of customers, surrounding circumstances, and likely use in normal course.
precedents.cited_holding: You must take the two words. You must Judge them, both by their look and by their sound. You must consider the goods to which they are to be applied. You must consider the nature and kind of customer who would be likely to buy those goods. In fact you must consider all the surrounding circumstances and you must further consider what is likely to happen if each of those trade marks is used in a normal way as a trade mark for the goods of the respective owners of the marks.

precedents.citation: Corn Products Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd (1)

anchor.surface_text: As we said in Corn Products Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd (1 ) the question has to be approached from the point of view of a man of average intelligence and imperfect recollection. To such a man the overall structural and phonetic similarity of the ,two names Amritdhara and Lakshmandbara is, in our, opinion likely. t deceive or cause companyfusion.

precedents.case_name: Corn Products Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Approach the question of deceptive similarity from the point of view of a man of average intelligence and imperfect recollection.

precedents.citation: William Bailey Bir- mingham Ltd.8 Application 1935 52 R.P.C. 137

anchor.surface_text: the whole word has to be companysidered a the case of the application to register Erectiks opposed by the proprietors of the trade mark Erector Farwell, J. said in William Bailey Bir- mingham Ltd.8 Application (1 ) 1935 52 R.P.C. 137. I do number think it is right to take a part of the word and companypare it with a part of the- other Word one word must be companysidered as a whole and companypared with the other word as a whole I think it is a danger- ous method to adopt to divide the word up, and seek to distinguish a portion of it from a portion of the other word.

precedents.cited_proposition: A trade mark must be considered as a whole and compared with the other word as a whole; it is dangerous to dissect parts of words.
precedents.cited_holding: I do not think it is right to take a part of the word and compare it with a part of the other word one word must be considered as a whole and compared with the other word as a whole I think it is a dangerous method to adopt to divide the word up, and seek to distinguish a portion of it from a portion of the other word.

justification_sets.label: Likelihood to Deceive or Cause Confusion Test support

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we would allow the appeal, set aside the Judgment and order of the High Court, and restore those of the Registrar of Trade Marks, Bombay

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and order set aside; Registrar's order dated September 10, 1953 restored (registration of Lakshmandhara permitted only in Uttar Pradesh)
directions: set aside the Judgment and order of the High Court
restore those of the Registrar of Trade Marks, Bombay, dated September 10. 1953

anchor.surface_text: As to the decisions in annexure A, it has been argued before us that they were number at all admissible by reason of ss. 40 to 43 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. On behalf of the appellant it has been companytended that they were admissible under s. 13 of the Evidence. Act as showing the particular instances... We companysider it unnecessary to decide this question for the purposes of this case because those decisions even if they are admissible under s. 13 do number throw any light on the question whether Amritdhara and Lakshmandhara so nearly resemble each other as to cause deception or companyfusion.
For these reasons, we would allow the appeal, set aside the Judgment and order of the High Court, and restore those of the Registrar of Trade Marks, Bombay
